citation.article-title: Thiomicrospira halophila sp. nov., a moderately halophilic, obligately chemolithoautotrophic, sulfur-oxidizing bacterium from hypersaline lakes
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Thiomicrospira halophila sp. nov.
Thiomicrospira halophila (ha.lo′phi.la. Gr. n. hals salt; Gr. adj. philos loving; N.L. fem. adj. halophila salt-loving).
Cells are Gram-negative vibrios (0.3–0.5×1–2 μm), highly motile due to a single polar flagellum.
Colonies on thiosulfate agar at 1–2 M NaCl reach a maximum diameter of 1 mm and are convex, circular and silver–white (because of sulfur accumulation).
Strictly aerobic, with a tendency for microaerophilism.
Grows chemolithoautotrophically with thiosulfate and sulfide, oxidizing them to sulfate with elemental sulfur as an intermediate.
Does not produce or oxidize polythionates.
Autotrophic growth with thiosulfate is possible within the range of 0.5–3.5 M NaCl (optimum 1.5 M) and at pH 6.5–8.5 (optimum pH 7.5–7.8).
Inorganic carbon is assimilated through the Calvin cycle.
Differs from the other Thiomicrospira species by its high salt tolerance and much higher G+C content of genomic DNA.
Represented by three closely related strains isolated from hypersaline inland lakes in south-western Siberia (Altai, Russia) with DNA G+C contents of between 56.1 and 57.1 mol%.
The type strain is HL 5T (=DSM 15072T=UNIQEM U 221T).
